settings.title: A1R0evo vs A1R0evoS – which road bike for racing should I choose?
settings.content: If you want maximum speed-to-weight in the mountains, choose the A1R0evoS. It uses the same frame design as the A1R0evo but with a Toray T1100 lay-up that achieves the same stiffness with less material, resulting in lower weight. If you want balanced race versatility, pick the A1R0evo: a Toray T800 all-rounder that’s ideal for circuits, rolling road races and rougher surfaces. We can confirm the right option for your racing and fit during your build consultation.

settings.title: What are the advantages of carbon fibre frames over aluminium for road racing?
settings.content: For road race bikes, carbon fibre allows more aerodynamic tube shaping, better stiffness-to-weight, and improved vibration damping versus aluminium. That means cleaner airflow, more of your effort turning into speed, and less road buzz – helping you hold your race position longer.

settings.title: What is the difference between road race bikes and endurance road bikes?
settings.content: Road race bike geometry puts you in a more aerodynamic position with sharper handling and higher frame stiffness – endurance road bikes prioritise comfort over long miles. Endurance builds often lean to wider tyres and comfort-focused components, while performance road bikes prioritise speed, precision and fast response.

settings.title: 1x vs 2x on a road bike for racing – which is better and why?
settings.content: Most road racing scenarios are best served by 2x because you get a wider usable range with smaller jumps between gears for improved cadence control. A 1x setup is simpler, but the larger steps between gears mean your chainring choice must closely match the course. In practice, choose 2x for mixed courses; consider 1x only if the route profile and your cadence targets make the gaps acceptable – our team can advise during your fitting consultation.
